oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An account of the hunting of porcupine and the practices that ensure its success (such as the treatment of their bones). The hunter is 'worked on' by the women before he goes to seek porcupine. The porcupine goes about only at night and remains inside its hole when the place is bright. 1) p.7375v: |han=kass'o experienced these practices himself, 2) p.7377v: an explanation of the term 'decayed arm', 3) p.7379v: notes on trees in Bushmanland (including the Krieboom), 4) p.7381v: an explanation of the |xam term kua kua ssi-kuiten, which is applied to the porcupine (and the |gipp, or Proteles), 5) p.7386v: an explanation of the term 'it becomes white', 6) p.7388v: (5 September 1878) on rainfall and the abundance of food ('laying down plenty'), 7) p.7390v: the |xam name for the openings in the porcupine's tail that make a rattling sound, 8) p.7391v: (4 September 1878) the behaviour of the 'summer's porcupine', 9) See also The little porcupine, 10) This story is found in Book VIII-16.
